title: Rapidly Progressive Dementia
scope: ** Urgent evaluation of cognitive decline progressing over weeks to months (typically <1-2 years from symptom onset to severe disability). Covers comprehensive workup to identify treatable causes including autoimmune encephalitis, infectious etiologies, toxic-metabolic causes, CNS malignancy, and prion disease (CJD). The key principle: assume a treatable cause exists until proven otherwise. Excludes typical slowly progressive dementias (Alzheimer's, FTD) unless presenting atypically fast, and acute delirium (<days).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Infection screen; hematologic malignancy; B12 deficiency (macrocytosis)
Hepatic encephalopathy (ammonia); renal failure (uremia); electrolyte abnormalities (Na, Ca); hypo/hyperglycemia
B12 deficiency — reversible cause of cognitive decline and myelopathy
Vasculitis screen; inflammatory conditions; infection; malignancy
Substance-related cognitive impairment; prescription drug toxicity

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Hashimoto encephalopathy (SREAT) — treatable with steroids even if euthyroid
CNS vasculitis (granulomatosis with polyangiitis, microscopic polyangiitis)
Multiple myeloma; POEMS; Waldenström; M-protein-associated neuropathy/encephalopathy
Wernicke encephalopathy — reversible with treatment; alcoholism, malnutrition, bariatric surgery
Wilson disease (young patients <50); acquired copper deficiency (zinc excess, gastric surgery)
Zinc excess causes copper deficiency → myeloneuropathy + cognitive decline
ANNA-1 (Hu), ANNA-2 (Ri), CRMP-5 (CV2), amphiphysin, PCA-1 (Yo), PCA-2, PCA-Tr (DNER), GAD65

Extended Workup (Second-line).item: Autoimmune encephalitis panel (serum) — NMDAR, LGI1, CASPR2, GABA-B, GABA-A, AMPA, DPPX, IgLON5
Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Treatable autoimmune encephalitis — most important reversible cause to identify

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: CJD biomarker; elevated in rapid neuronal destruction. Sensitivity ~90% but NOT specific (also elevated in stroke, encephalitis, seizures)
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Negative (positive supports CJD in right clinical context)

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: MOST SPECIFIC test for prion disease; sensitivity 92%, specificity 99-100%. Gold standard CSF prion test
Markedly elevated in CJD (>1150 pg/mL); also elevated in AD but less extreme
Elevated in CJD (>35 ng/mL); marker of neuronal damage
Rapidly progressive Alzheimer disease (rpAD) is the most common misdiagnosis of CJD; AD biomarker pattern distinguishes
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio normal; p-tau/t-tau ratio helps distinguish

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.item: Neurofilament light chain (NfL) (CPT 83519) — CSF or serum
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Non-specific marker of neuronal damage; markedly elevated in CJD, moderately in many RPDs

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.item: Whipple disease PCR (CSF and duodenal biopsy)
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Tropheryma whipplei — rare but treatable cause of RPD with oculomasticatory myorhythmia; GI symptoms, arthralgia
Genetic prion disease (familial CJD, fatal familial insomnia, GSS); family history of early dementia or movement disorder

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Elevated ICP in mass, hydrocephalus, venous thrombosis
Pleocytosis suggests infection, autoimmune, or lymphoma; normal in CJD
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal in CJD; elevated in autoimmune/infectious

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Elevated in infection, inflammation, malignancy; mildly elevated or normal in CJD
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal or mildly elevated in CJD; elevated in infection/autoimmune

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Low in bacterial/TB/fungal meningitis, carcinomatous meningitis
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal in CJD, autoimmune; low in infectious/malignant

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Most sensitive and specific CSF test for prion disease (sensitivity 92%, specificity 99-100%)
CJD biomarker; rapid neuronal destruction marker
Markedly elevated in CJD (>1150 pg/mL); moderately elevated in AD

Lumbar Puncture.item: Autoimmune encephalitis panel (CSF) — NMDAR, LGI1, CASPR2, GABA-B, GABA-A, AMPA, DPPX
Lumbar Puncture.rationale: CSF more sensitive than serum for NMDAR antibodies; identifies treatable autoimmune etiology
More sensitive than serum for some antibodies

Lumbar Puncture.item: Cytology (send 10 mL minimum; repeat x3 for sensitivity)
Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Leptomeningeal carcinomatosis/lymphoma; sensitivity improves with volume and repeat
rpAD pattern: low Aβ42, elevated p-tau; helps distinguish from CJD (where p-tau is NOT as elevated relative to t-tau)
Non-specific neuronal damage; very elevated in CJD

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553) + DWI
Essential/First-line.timing: Within 24h. DWI is CRITICAL — cortical ribboning on DWI is highly suggestive of CJD
Essential/First-line.target: CJD: cortical ribboning (DWI/FLAIR high signal in cortex), caudate/putamen signal. Autoimmune: mesial temporal T2/FLAIR. Vasculitis: multifocal white matter lesions. Lymphoma: enhancing mass. Wernicke: mamillary body/thalamic signal. MS: periventricular/juxtacortical lesions
CJD: periodic sharp wave complexes (PSWCs) at 1-2 Hz — sensitivity ~65% (higher in sCJD-MM1). Seizures: electrographic activity. NCSE: subclinical seizures. Autoimmune: extreme delta brush (NMDAR)

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediate if acute presentation or focal deficit
Essential/First-line.target: Mass lesion, hydrocephalus, hemorrhage, large infarct

Extended.timing: If vasculitis or venous thrombosis suspected
If concurrent myelopathy (B12 deficiency, copper deficiency, neurosarcoidosis)
Extended.target: Cord signal change (posterior columns in B12/copper); sarcoid enhancement

Extended.timing: Differentiate neurodegenerative patterns; detect occult malignancy; autoimmune encephalitis (mesial temporal hypermetabolism)
Extended.target: AD: temporoparietal hypometabolism. FTD: frontal/temporal. CJD: cortical/striatal. Lymphoma: hypermetabolic mass. Autoimmune: mesial temporal hypermetabolism

Extended.timing: If CNS vasculitis suspected (MRA normal does not exclude small-vessel vasculitis)
Testicular germ cell tumor (paraneoplastic; anti-NMDAR in males)
Ovarian teratoma (anti-NMDAR encephalitis — present in 50% of young women)

Rare/Specialized.timing: Last resort when all non-invasive testing inconclusive; suspected CNS vasculitis, intravascular lymphoma, or prion disease where RT-QuIC unavailable
Rare/Specialized.target: Vasculitis (vessel wall inflammation); lymphoma (atypical cells); prion disease (spongiform change, PrP immunostaining)

Rare/Specialized.timing: If intravascular lymphoma, hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH), or hematologic malignancy suspected
Fatal familial insomnia (FFI) — complete loss of sleep architecture
Rare/Specialized.target: Absent sleep spindles; disrupted sleep architecture

Empiric / Treatable Causes — TREAT WHILE.indication: Empiric for Wernicke encephalopathy if ANY suspicion (alcohol, malnutrition, bariatric surgery); treat before glucose

dosing.instructions: 500 mg IV TID x 3-5 days, then 250 mg IV daily x 3-5 days, then 100 mg PO daily ongoing

Empiric / Treatable Causes — TREAT WHILE.monitoring: Clinical response (confusion, ataxia, ophthalmoplegia should improve)

Empiric / Treatable Causes — TREAT WHILE.indication: Suspected autoimmune encephalitis, Hashimoto encephalopathy (SREAT), neurosarcoidosis, CNS vasculitis

dosing.instructions: 1000 mg IV daily x 3-5 days. Consider when autoimmune etiology suspected and workup pending. Document pre-treatment baseline exam.

Empiric / Treatable Causes — TREAT WHILE.contraindications: Active infection (rule out first); uncertain prion disease (steroids do not help CJD and may mask diagnosis)
Empiric / Treatable Causes — TREAT WHILE.monitoring: Glucose q6h; BP; GI prophylaxis; response assessment

Empiric / Treatable Causes — TREAT WHILE.indication: Suspected autoimmune encephalitis; concurrent with steroid trial

dosing.instructions: 0.4 g/kg/day x 5 days (total 2 g/kg). Add to steroids or as alternative if steroid-intolerant

Empiric / Treatable Causes — TREAT WHILE.contraindications: IgA deficiency; renal failure; thrombotic risk

Empiric / Treatable Causes — TREAT WHILE.indication: Empiric while awaiting HSV PCR; fever + encephalopathy

dosing.instructions: 10 mg/kg IV q8h. Continue until HSV PCR confirmed negative

Targeted Treatments (Once Diagnosis Esta.indication: Autoimmune encephalitis; Hashimoto encephalopathy (SREAT); CNS vasculitis; neurosarcoidosis

doseOptions.orderSentence: IV methylprednisolone (CPT 96365) → oral prednisone taper 1g IV

dosing.instructions: 1g IV x 5d → prednisone 1 mg/kg/day with slow taper over 3-6 months
dosing.orderSentence: IV methylprednisolone (CPT 96365) → oral prednisone taper 1g IV

Targeted Treatments (Once Diagnosis Esta.monitoring: Glucose, BP, bone density, weight, mood

dosing.instructions: 0.4 g/kg/day x 5 days; repeat monthly for maintenance

Targeted Treatments (Once Diagnosis Esta.indication: Refractory autoimmune encephalitis (NMDAR, LGI1); B-cell depletion

dosing.instructions: 375 mg/m2 IV weekly x 4 weeks OR 1000 mg IV x 2 doses (2 weeks apart)

Targeted Treatments (Once Diagnosis Esta.monitoring: CD19/20 counts; immunoglobulins; infection risk; PML risk

Targeted Treatments (Once Diagnosis Esta.indication: CNS vasculitis; refractory autoimmune encephalitis; PCNSL induction

dosing.instructions: 750-1000 mg/m2 IV monthly x 6 months (pulse) OR oral 1-2 mg/kg/day

Targeted Treatments (Once Diagnosis Esta.monitoring: CBC (nadir at 10-14 days); urinalysis (hemorrhagic cystitis — give MESNA); fertility preservation discussion

Targeted Treatments (Once Diagnosis Esta.indication: Neurosyphilis (positive CSF VDRL or high clinical suspicion)

doseOptions.orderSentence: Penicillin G IV (CPT 96365) 18-24 million units IV

dosing.instructions: 18-24 million units/day IV (3-4 MU q4h) x 14 days
dosing.orderSentence: Penicillin G IV (CPT 96365) 18-24 million units IV

Targeted Treatments (Once Diagnosis Esta.monitoring: RPR titer follow-up q3-6 months (4-fold decline expected)

Targeted Treatments (Once Diagnosis Esta.indication: Paraneoplastic syndrome with identified primary tumor

dosing.instructions: Per oncology

Targeted Treatments (Once Diagnosis Esta.indication: Anti-NMDAR encephalitis with ovarian teratoma (50% of young women)

dosing.instructions: Surgical removal

Targeted Treatments (Once Diagnosis Esta.indication: B12 deficiency (<200 pg/mL) with cognitive decline; subacute combined degeneration

dosing.instructions: Cyanocobalamin 1000 µg IM daily x 7 days, then weekly x 4, then monthly long-term

Targeted Treatments (Once Diagnosis Esta.monitoring: B12 and MMA levels at 3 months

dosing.instructions: Amphotericin B 0.7-1 mg/kg/day IV + flucytosine 100 mg/kg/day x 2 weeks (induction)

Targeted Treatments (Once Diagnosis Esta.indication: TB meningitis (AFB positive or high clinical suspicion)

dosing.instructions: RIPE: rifampin + isoniazid + pyrazinamide + ethambutol

Targeted Treatments (Once Diagnosis Esta.indication: Prion disease (CJD confirmed); no effective treatment exists

dosing.instructions: Supportive care only; no effective treatment exists

Targeted Treatments (Once Diagnosis Esta.monitoring: Comfort care; goals of care discussion

dosing.instructions: 500-1500 mg PO/IV BID; max 3000 mg/day
0.5-1 mg PO/IV q6-8h PRN
0.5 mg PO BID; increase to 1-2 mg TID
250-500 mg PO BID; target level 50-100 µg/mL
25-50 mg PO qHS; increase by 25 mg/day; max 200-400 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: QT prolongation; Parkinson disease (avoid all antipsychotics in Lewy body)

dosing.instructions: 25-50 mg PO qHS; max 150 mg
3-10 mg PO qHS

Referrals & Consults.indication: All RPD cases; diagnostic workup direction; empiric treatment decisions
Suspected CNS infection (neurosyphilis, TB, HIV, fungal, Whipple)
Paraneoplastic syndrome; CNS lymphoma; brain metastases
Suspected CNS vasculitis; lupus cerebritis; sarcoidosis
Formal cognitive testing; baseline and follow-up
Goals of care (especially if CJD suspected); symptom management
Family support; advance directive planning; caregiver resources
If genetic prion disease suspected; family implications
End-of-life decisions; capacity evaluation for untreatable conditions

Referrals & Consults.item: National Prion Disease Pathology Surveillance Center (Cleveland)
Referrals & Consults.indication: If CJD suspected: contact for diagnostic guidance and potential brain autopsy

Patient and Family Instructions.item: RPD has many TREATABLE causes — aggressive workup is justified
Return to ED if: new seizure, sudden worsening, falls, inability to swallow, fever
Ensure 24/7 supervision at home (fall risk, wandering, impaired judgment)
Advance directives / healthcare power of attorney should be completed early while patient can still participate
If CJD is diagnosed: no cure exists; disease is uniformly fatal; focus on comfort and quality of life
CJD is NOT contagious through casual contact; standard precautions are sufficient; no isolation needed for family
CJD surgical instruments: notify any surgical/dental providers about diagnosis (special sterilization or instrument destruction required)
Family support resources: CJD Foundation (www.cjdfoundation.org); Autoimmune Encephalitis Alliance
Follow-up with neurology frequently (weekly to monthly depending on trajectory)

Lifestyle & Safety.item: Fall prevention (remove tripping hazards, grab bars, non-slip surfaces)
Medication management by caregiver (patient cannot reliably self-administer)
Nutritional support (swallowing may decline; SLP evaluation)

differential.features: Weeks-months; myoclonus; startle; akinetic mutism late; MRI cortical ribboning + caudate/putamen DWI signal; PSWCs on EEG
differential.tests: RT-QuIC (CSF); 14-3-3; total tau >1150; MRI DWI; EEG

differential.features: Subacute; psychiatric symptoms → seizures → movement disorder → autonomic → decreased consciousness; young women; ovarian teratoma
Faciobrachial dystonic seizures; hyponatremia; memory loss; >40 years
Euthyroid or hypothyroid; high anti-TPO; steroid-responsive; diagnosis of exclusion
differential.tests: Anti-TPO elevated; response to steroids; exclude other causes

differential.features: Most common misdiagnosis of CJD; positive AD biomarkers (low Aβ42, high p-tau); no myoclonus typically; MRI shows atrophy, no DWI ribboning
differential.tests: CSF AD biomarkers (Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio low, p-tau elevated); MRI (atrophy without DWI cortical signal); RT-QuIC negative

differential.features: B symptoms; enhancing mass (primary); multifocal white matter changes with LDH elevation and no mass (intravascular)
differential.tests: MRI with contrast; CSF cytology + flow cytometry; EBV PCR; brain biopsy; LDH; peripheral smear

differential.features: Known malignancy; cranial neuropathies; communicating hydrocephalus; CSF cytology positive
differential.tests: CSF cytology (repeat x3); MRI with contrast (leptomeningeal enhancement)

differential.features: RPR/VDRL positive; Argyll Robertson pupils; psychiatric symptoms; may have prior STI history
Acute confusion + ophthalmoplegia + ataxia triad (only 10% have all three); alcoholism, malnutrition
differential.tests: Thiamine level (draw before treatment); MRI (mamillary body, thalamic signal); clinical response to thiamine

differential.features: Headache; multifocal deficits; strokes; CSF pleocytosis
differential.tests: MRA (beading); DSA; brain/meningeal biopsy; ESR/CRP elevated

differential.features: Cranial neuropathies (CN VII); leptomeningeal enhancement; hilar adenopathy; elevated ACE
Triad: gait disorder (predominant) + urinary incontinence + dementia; "wet, wobbly, and wacky"; ventricular enlargement disproportionate to atrophy
differential.tests: Large-volume LP (30-50 mL) with pre/post gait assessment; MRI (Evans index >0.3)

differential.features: Medication toxicity (lithium, methotrexate, chemotherapy); substance abuse; hepatic/uremic encephalopathy
differential.tests: Drug levels; LFTs; ammonia; BUN/Cr; UDS

differential.features: Depressive symptoms predominant; subjective cognitive complaints > objective deficits; onset correlates with depressive episode
differential.tests: Neuropsychological testing; psychiatric evaluation; may improve with antidepressant

differential.features: Oculomasticatory myorhythmia (pathognomonic); GI symptoms; arthralgia; chronic diarrhea
differential.tests: T. whipplei PCR (CSF, duodenal biopsy); PAS-positive macrophages on biopsy

differential.features: Immunocompromised; multifocal white matter lesions (no enhancement typically); progressive deficits
differential.tests: JC virus PCR (CSF); MRI pattern; clinical context

differential.features: Genetic prion disease; progressive insomnia → autonomic dysfunction → motor signs → dementia; family history
differential.tests: PRNP gene testing (D178N mutation with 129M); polysomnography (absent sleep spindles)

evidence.source: [McGuire et al. (Ann Neurol 2012)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22926858/); [Atarashi et al. (Nat Med 2011)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21278748/)

evidence.recommendation: MRI DWI cortical ribboning for CJD
CSF 14-3-3 protein for CJD (sensitivity ~90%, lower specificity)
Comprehensive autoimmune antibody testing in RPD
evidence.source: [Graus et al. (Lancet Neurol 2016)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26906964/) — diagnostic criteria for autoimmune encephalitis

evidence.recommendation: Empiric immunotherapy trial for suspected autoimmune encephalitis

evidence.source: [Castillo et al. (Arch Neurol 2006)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16476807/); diagnosis of exclusion

evidence.recommendation: Thiamine for Wernicke: high-dose IV (500 mg TID)
Neurosyphilis: IV penicillin G x 14 days
CJD: no effective treatment; supportive care only
evidence.source: No disease-modifying therapy exists; multiple trials failed

evidence.recommendation: Brain biopsy when non-invasive workup inconclusive
evidence.source: Expert consensus; diagnostic yield 57-65% in RPD

evidence.recommendation: Save CSF frozen for future studies

monitoring.item: Cognitive assessment (MMSE, MoCA, or bedside exam)
monitoring.frequency: Baseline; weekly inpatient; each visit outpatient

monitoring.item: Neurologic exam (focal signs, myoclonus, gait, cranial nerves)
monitoring.action: If new focal signs: repeat MRI; if myoclonus: add clonazepam

monitoring.frequency: q12-24h initially; then per clinical indication
monitoring.action: SIADH management if low; LGI1 encephalitis associated with hyponatremia

monitoring.frequency: Daily if on acyclovir or nephrotoxic drugs; weekly otherwise
Assess at day 5 of steroids/IVIG; then weekly
monitoring.action: If no response: consider second-line (rituximab); reconsider diagnosis
If rising: relapse risk; adjust immunotherapy
Increase supervision; facility placement if needed

disposition.criteria: Stable cognition; safe home environment with 24/7 caregiver; outpatient workup can be completed; no active seizures; swallowing safe; outpatient follow-up arranged within 1-2 weeks
Acute/subacute decline requiring urgent workup; unable to safely manage at home; seizures; empiric immunotherapy trial; cannot complete workup as outpatient
Status epilepticus; respiratory failure; autonomic instability; severe agitation requiring sedation; ICP management
Complex workup (brain biopsy, specialized autoimmune testing); prion disease expertise; clinical trial access
Progressive untreatable dementia (CJD, advanced neurodegenerative); unable to care for self; caregiver unable to manage
Confirmed CJD or other untreatable rapidly fatal diagnosis; focus on comfort
